DESCRIPTION OF THE FACILITY AND THE REGULATED SUBSTANCE:

Perdue Farms Incorporated, founded in 1920, is the largest poultry producer in the Northeast and the third largest in the United States.  Headquartered in Salisbury, Maryland, the family-owned, privately held company has operations in 13 states.  Fifteen processing facilities produce about 50 million pounds of poultry products each week.  Perdue also has grain storage and merchandising operations and is ranked among the top 20 largest US grain companies.  In addition, Perdue manufactures edible oils, specialty feeds, livestock feed ingredients, and premium pet food ingredients.



The Perdue Farms, Perry  Poultry Processing Complex is located at 250 Highway 247 Spur in Perry, Georgia.  This Complex processes broilers and other value-add fresh and frozen poultry product that employes approximately 2,053 associates in two plants.  The facility normally operates 24 hours a day, five days per week.



The regulated substance at the Perry facility, covered by 40 CFR Part 68, is anhydrous ammonia (R-717).  The facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia as an integral part of its refrigeration system.  The refrigeration system consisits of several storage vessels, compressors, condensers, piping, and air handling units located throughout the facility, in order to maintain proper food safety temperatures.  The total quantity of anhydrous ammonia on-site is approximately 179,103 pounds distributed throughout the refrigeration components.



ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPOINSE POLICIES:

As a concerned member of the community, the company takes its role as a responsible corporate citizen very seriously.  All Perdue facilities are operated to protect employees, contractors, and the public from injury and illness, and to minimize environmental impact.  A company-wide safety and wellness program stresses safe conditions and safe practices.  Perdue's policy is to inspect, maintain, and operate equipment and faci

lities to prevent accidents, including release of hazardous materials; and to train employees in prevention, as well as to prepare them to respond rapidly and effetively should an accident occur.



Perdue Farms has developed and implemented Spill Prevention Control and Countermeasures (SPCC) and Process Safety Management (PSM) plans as part of an overall chemical management program.  The program involves a wide-range of senior management personnel, including the Vice President of Environmental Services and the Director of  Safety and Security.  Additionally, Perdue conducts regular safety meetings and provides a wide variety of environmenatl, health, and safety training to its staff.



GENERAL ACCIDENT RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM:

The Perdue Farms Perry facility maintains a Process Safety Management (PSM) Plan in accordance with the Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA) regulation 29 CFR 1910.119.  The maintenance personnel at the facility utilize a preventative maintenance program for all the system components.  As part of the program, trained refrigeration personnel routinely inspect the refrigeration system operating parameters and conduct routine maintenance as needed.



FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY:

There are no incidents meeting reporting criteria.



EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM:

 In the event of an emergency involving our ammonia refrigeration system, Perdue's Perry facility has a well defined incident command system. The written Emergency Response program includes procedures to safely evacuate the facility, minimize and/or contain the release and notify the appropriate local fire department and LECP officials. Perdue continues to train our associates on hazardous responses and awareness, and conduct mock drills routinely. Perdue's officials have discussed the company's response program with our local fire department representatives.  



PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY:

As part of Perdue Farms' continual improvement philosophy, the Perdue
Perry facility continues to identify and update system components and techniques to ensure safety and quality.
